Title.evidence: Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Costs of Open vs Endovascular Repair of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 881 patients were randomised to open repair (n = 437) or EVR (n = 444)

Participants.evidence: 881 patients were randomised to open repair (n = 437) or EVR (n = 444) at Veterans Affairs (VA) hospitals.

Intervention.evidence: 881 patients were randomised to open repair (n = 437) or EVR (n = 444)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the costs associated with different endograft systems used in endovascular repair (EVR) of abdominal aortic aneurysm compared to open repair

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the total health care cost from randomisation to 2 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not specified.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 881 patients were randomised to open repair (n = 437) or EVR (n = 444)

Result_Outcome.evidence: Mean device, initial hospitalisation, and total health care costs at 2 years were not significantly different among device systems.
